document.title: Indiana Department of Education College and Career Readiness

96F415B69A1A46CC9EF396AFE6BC6538.description:
Formulate and present a position or course of action on an issue by examining the underlying factors contributing to
that issue.

8B417A614BDB4B969BFBF26C6E9FD838.description: Explain issues and problems of the past by analyzing the interests and viewpoints of those involved.

4F38194631944FBCB842D6FB3CC81185.description: Analyze multiple, unexpected, and complex causes and effects of events in the past

210BF59D6A334D3E933CD6BAC8AF3E67.description:
Locate and analyze primary sources and secondary sources related to an event or issue of the past; discover
possible limitations in various kinds of historical evidence and differing secondary opinions.

F7D56D7F06504D699786FB81C6B033D4.description:
Identify patterns of historical succession and duration in which historical events have unfolded and apply them to
explain continuity and change.

7F7A48D8FB5E44AAA742A3B7256270C4.description:
Analyze the impact of globalization on U.S. culture and U.S. economic, political and foreign policy. (Government,
Economics, Geography)

2ABB59ACA2E84ADE915BB161B228F9B7.description: Explain the background and significance of the September 11, 2001 terrorist attack and the resulting War on Terror.

4786F0F44FC347ECA8463FD89CEA7EB6.description:
Explain the constitutional significance of the following landmark decisions of the United States Supreme Court:
Westside Community School District v. Mergens (1990), Reno v. American Civil Liberties Union (1997), Mitchell v.
Helms (2000) and Bush v. Gore (2000).

5994AFDAB98D43FC9460DB13C1373E2B.description: Analyze important domestic and foreign policies and events of the Clinton and Bush administrations.

D1D782907A9C4F1EAAD46ED49B57CFC2.description:
Explain how the Cold War ended and identify new challenges to U.S. leadership in the world. (Economics,
Geography)

DF1FE87B4DD74F20BB970E1870D80C86.description:
Explain the assumptions of supply-side economics or "Reaganomics" and how the Reagan administration
implemented it. (Economics)

B6D48098CB1E42789925356B88FB2A21.description: Discuss and explain the significance of the rise of the new conservative coalition of the 1980’s.

2F99091EE8B04C50959A294441FA6770.description:
Describe developing trends in science and technology and explain how they impact the lives of Americans today
such as: NASA and space programs; identification of DNA; the Internet; global climate change; and U.S. energy
policy.

FEB8D58003184D33A1C7E9CB53460713.description:
Explain the significance of social, economic and political issues during the period 1980 to the present and how
these issues affected individuals and organizations.

F00B3385382B483A85225FCC5F34BD33.description: The Contemporary United States: 1980 to the Present

99AC18621AE74D12B39485D9995E84E1.description:
Explain the constitutional, political, and cultural significance of the Watergate Scandal and the United States
Supreme Court decision of United States v. Nixon. (Government)

637E4755CB12492EB64C9F637FA96B2F.description: Explain and analyze U.S. foreign policy issues during the 1960s and 1970s. (Africa, Middle East, China)

06851BD590F14DBFB61E0BC3A0B382D6.description: Analyze the foreign and domestic consequences of U.S. involvement in Vietnam.

F7756EF5B85D4719BB52C1D8088878A3.description: Explain and analyze changing relations between the United States and the Soviet Union from 1960 to 1980.

C126E251F91B48F685DD04468CE8BECE.description: Identify areas of social tension from this time period and explain how social attitudes shifted as a result.

659CAC3338544FC2A93AC60901D8ABD5.description:
Identify the problems confronting different minorities during this period of economic and social change and describe
the solutions to these problems. (Economics; Individuals, Society and Culture)

34906004CF5044BE8A093C413DC96014.description: Identify and analyze the significance of key decisions of the Warren Court. (Government)

93DDEFEADE724D16A63B775EA6A414C4.description:
Describe developing trends in science and technology and explain how they impacted the lives of Americans during
the period 1960-1980.

1259E65FB8BB4BF4B4B5398F92871289.description:
Identify and explain the significance of federal programs, policies and legal rulings designed to improve the lives of
Americans during the 1960s. (Government, Economics)

6F0DE494CA994A3E9E05F31ED4B49179.description:
Evaluate various methods and philosophies (e.g. Martin Luther King, Jr., the Black Panthers, and Malcolm X) to bring
about social justice during the Civil Rights Movement. (Individuals, Society and Culture)

9AA4980A11DB4FCE911EB997D0FA32BD.description: The United States in Troubled Times: 1960 to 1980

0DEB500DB17640C286C701B5F725861E.description: Summarize key economic and social changes in post-WW II American life. (Individuals, Society and Culture)

08A4577D1C8540C7AA495AC8E91CFB03.description:
Describe the constitutional significance and lasting societal effects of the United States Brown v. Board of Education
 Supreme Court case. (Government)

61B5D7DD527F433D9FE0112FA5CAB642.description:
Summarize and assess the various actions which characterized the early struggle for civil rights (1945-1960).
(Government; Individuals, Society and Culture)

CDBCB1C528FB4B588557963973EE8ECB.description:
Understand the domino theory and its relationship to the principle of containment. Identify key events and individuals
as well as their connections to post World War II tensions (Cold War). (Government, Geography)

373F07CCB26C45528FAF84984DB51748.description: Explain how World War II led to the rise of the United States and the Soviet Union as rival superpowers.

7A886179FA404C2E83C3F8E9E664CA59.description: Identify and describe the impact of World War II on American culture. (Individuals, Society and Culture)

BB2FAB569BC94F5299D2A8EB1ABB7A60.description:
Summarize the efforts the national government made to regulate production, labor, and prices during the war and
evaluate the success or failure of these efforts. (Government)

0CDEB50A18544119B5A2C936A4BABA43.description:
Explain how the United States dealt with individual rights and national security during World War II by examining the
following groups: Japanese-Americans, African Americans, Native-Americans, Hispanics, and women.
(Government)

9A334991829746859FB9DD697C7AC5A2.description:
Describe Hitler’s “final solution” policy and explain the Allied responses to the Holocaust and war crimes.
 (Government; Geography; Individuals, Society and Culture)

AE75E4F5EC5046C9A32072AC7A6213BB.description: Identify key leaders and events from World War II and explain the significance of each. (Government)

16A3B994EA984330A89AF11AC0F294C6.description:
Identify and explain key events from Versailles to Pearl Harbor that resulted in the United States entry into
World War II. (Government, Geography)

28FA75B95A7B4846B2C4CB2484CCA10E.description:
Compare and contrast President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s world view with that of Germany’s Adolf Hitler, Italy’s Benito
Mussolini, the Soviet Union’s Joseph Stalin, and Japan’s Hideki Tojo. (Government; Individuals, Society and Culture)

78EE0C8423E5495E9980AA15ECFB61FE.description:
Analyze the causes and effects of American isolationism during the 1930s and the effect this policy had on America’s
war preparation. (Government, Economics, Geography)

EFED25A992A9414D9DAFAB644253AEC1.description: The United States and World War II: 1939 to 1945

B5AC54C3ED7942A584CCF00B0EA8E558.description:
Identify and explain the significance of the expansion of federal power during the New Deal Era in the areas of
agriculture, money and banking, industry, labor, social welfare, and conservation.

6CEB412AB8DA44528959F6E366DECF0B.description: Identify and explain the significance of New Deal relief programs. (Government)

E4F8EFD588014279A88CCDDD3399F255.description: Analyze the impact the Great Depression had on America’s standard of living (Economics, Government)

BB6D705CCAEA40E3B641D4D167ACCE88.description:
Identify and describe the contributions of political and social reformers during the Great Depression Era.
(Government; Economics; Individuals, Society and Culture)

49129B090B6140C8B3041CC524FC1BF4.description:
Analyze the causes of the Great Depression and explain how they affected American society. (Economics;
Individuals, Society, and Culture)

0CE9569E1A814F159048EA3EB0FFAB60.description:
Describe technological developments during the 1920s and explain their impact on rural and urban America.
(Economics; Geography; Individuals, Society, and Culture)

4720985EDD4043CFA1ED517B14A2A472.description:
Identify areas of social tension such as the Red Scare, Prohibition, Religious Fundamentalism, the KKK,
New Morality, and the New Woman and explain their consequences in the post-WWI era. (Individuals, Society, and
Culture)

37BE4038EAE24CB09F239194D0881AF7.description:
Identify new cultural movements of the 1920s and analyze how these movements reflected and changed American
society. (Individuals, Society, and Culture)

ECC2A3E3E34A488182EF29B98626AFC3.description:
Understand the significance of the pro-business policies of President’s Harding, Coolidge, and Hoover and the effect
these policies had on the economy of the 1920s. (Economics, Government)

C7CA75DD076340A594A11D83594FE733.description: Modern United States Prosperity and Depression: Post WW I - 1939

FF60C764A5354884A0AADF46B9208604.description:
Explain the impact of “New” Immigration and the Great Migration on industrialization and urbanization and in
promoting economic growth. (Economics, Geography)

478E86B8709A4D229CADEA497A13C931.description:
Summarize the provisions of the Treaty of Versailles and analyze reasons why the treaty was never ratified by the
U.S. Senate. (Government)

33AAE2B5452D47FB9CE7EB0A5E22244F.description:
Analyze President Wilson’s Fourteen Points and describe the obstacles he faced in getting European leaders to
accept his approach to peace. (Government)

C2FBEAA232D24E10BED13E0D6123F238.description: Analyze the reasons why the United States became involved in World War I. (Government, Economics)

251B608873AC4B10B28DEEA1F176C375.description:
Identify and give the significance of contributions to American culture made by individuals and groups--1897-1920
such as Booker T. Washington, W.E.B. DuBois, NAACP, muckrakers, Upton Sinclair. (Individuals, Society, and
Culture)

F58CEA4C96ED4BBDBF7CCF6B36C886F3.description:
Explain the constitutional significance of the following landmark decisions of the United States Supreme Court:
Northern Securities Company v. United States (1904), Muller v. Oregon (1908), Schenck v. United States (1919) and
Abrams v. United States (1919).

0F044608B24F4EA78A9651B8B7DECEAA.description:
Compare and contrast the Progressive reforms of Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and Woodrow Wilson.
(Government; Economics; Individuals, Society, and Culture)

4931BB9819CF4518B1E5E83042BABBB3.description:
Explain the origins, goals, achievements, and limitations of the Progressive Movement in addressing political,
economic, and social reform. (Government; Economics; Individuals, Society, and Culture)

3E71C7F9F56C4E9787782C7C9D675850.description:
Describe the events and people central to the transformation of the United States developing into a world power.
(Government, Geography)

121B56D38D964169848B15D409F1E7FA.description: Emergence of the Modern United States: 1897 to 1920

610B26BBD5E94C43A175BEF52E9168FA.description:
Analyze the development of “separate but equal” policies culminating in the Plessy v. Ferguson (1896) case.
(Government; Individuals, Society, and Culture)

0F054234D1394F0D83C6408831DFCBE8.description:
Evaluate the effectiveness of government attempts to regulate business (Interstate and Commerce Act-1887,
Sherman Anti-Trust Act 1890). (Government, Economics)

A196298552E74AC286D79163E6D3CE6A.description:
Describe and assess the contribution of Indiana’s only president, Benjamin Harrison, to national policies on
 environmental protection, business regulation, immigration, and civil rights.

E485342226814889BEDFC9E3FD9356B7.description:
Describe the growth of unions and the labor movement and evaluate various approaches and methods used by
different labor leaders and organizations. (Government, Economics)

76405084B023482DA5BD57B004929713.description:
Summarize the impact industrialization and immigration had on social movements of the era including the
contributions specific individuals and groups. (Economics, Geography, Individuals, Society, and Culture)

AF3BDB349F95467A85FDBB82AD912E63.description:
Explain how the lives of American Indians changed with the development of the West. (Government, Individuals,
Society, and Culture)

85B9BBF030534512A92F1D402425C834.description:
Analyze the factors associated with the development of the West and how these factors affected the lives of those
who settled there. (Government, Economics, Individuals, Society, and Culture)

47291D1CAC87485C831B1232660DB2EA.description:
Explain key ideas, movements, and inventions and summarize their impact on rural and urban communities
throughout the United States. (Economics, Sociology)

B41A00898AC64B8D98F7EB4C58CA0890.description:
Describe the economic developments that transformed the United States into a major industrial power and the factors
necessary for industrialization. (Economics)

EC351CBCCE2848ED8A053C0DF6284B9F.description: Development of the Industrial United States: 1870 to 1900

B2216AAE320C471CB3BBFAF6367C33DF.description:
Describe causes and lasting effects of the Civil War and Reconstruction as well as the political controversies
surrounding this time such as Andrew Johnson’s impeachment, the Black Codes, and the Compromise of
1877. (Government, Economics)

02EF1C8095A343E69B866CEE4E16B075.description:
Identify and tell the significance of controversies pertaining to slavery, abolitionism, and social reform
movements. (Government, Economics)

77BCDF1F2CBA4E339B674A5E48661FCB.description:
Summarize major themes in the early history of the United States such as federalism, sectionalism,
nationalism, and states’ rights. (Economics, Government)

560E56A55921485DAC93C1965D103769.description:
Read key documents from the Founding Era and analyze major ideas about government, individual rights
and the general welfare embedded in these documents. (Government)
http://www.ourdocuments.gov/content.php?flash=true&page=milestone
